The NURSE taking the IV out of her arm, and placing a vial of blood on a tray with several others. Peggy sits up slowly, dazed and frightened. She looks at the nurse.

direction.raw_text: You're kidding...? Carol, you have beautiful hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on. What's with you and Michael?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. He's so cool and mysterious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's very interesting. For all his pretending to be a tough guy, he's really got the soul of a poet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I bet Dolores told Charlie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That loudmouthed little bitch~
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy Sue!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You better watch out for her. She's after Charlie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cool it kids. He's free to see other girls, if he wants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I always thought that you would marry Charlie, Carol would marry Walter, and I would marry Arthur. We'd all live on the same street and take our kids to the park together and have barbecues every Sunday. It'll spoil everything if you and Charlie break up. That Michael doesn't look like the barbecue type.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not going to marry him. I just went out with him once. (beat) I know! Why don't we go to the movies tonight. Just us girls. It'll be fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be silly. It's Saturday. Date night!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah. I've gotta go. Arthur's picking me up soon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. But let's have a girls night soon. Maybe a pajama party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aren't we a little old for that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sometimes you're so immature.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy turns to face her parents, holding up her homemade pantyhose with a flourish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ta da! Pantyhose! The death of the garter belt! Of course, once they're manufactured they'll look better than this. What do you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is your great invention? (to Mrs. Kelcher) Would you wear those things?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would they go over my girdle or under?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Instead of a girdle. And light as a feather.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack, I think she's got something there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And we won't just sell them in department stores. We'll market them in drug stores and supermarkets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all well and good, but we don't have the money to manufacture them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You need a partner. There's a friend of mine at school whose father makes seat covers for cars, Mr. Fitzsimmons. I've invited him and his family over for dinner tomorrow night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't that awfully forward?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've got to move fast. This is an idea whose time has come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean to tell me that you invited this Mr. Fitzsimmons over to talk about investing his money in your cockamamie idea?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wrong, Dad. Your idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PEGGY'S BEDROOM  NIGHT A breeze blows through the open window Peggy sleeps fitfully, tossing off the covers. We HEAR NOISES from outside her window. A figure appears outside and silently climbs into the bedroom. Peggy mumbles Charlie's name. The man walks over to her bed as Peggy reaches out for him, tenderly, as if they were still married.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie. I just had the strangest dream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to talk to you.. Through her sleepclouded eyes, Peggy begins to focus on the face of the younger Charlie. Suddenly, she remembers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's go down to the basement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy enters, flicks on the light and leads Charlie in. Peggy senses Charlie's anger, and steels herself for the inevitable confrontation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to know what's going on. Dolores told me that you and that scuzzball Michael Fitzsimmons...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I bumped into him after you dropped me off Last night. I didn't feel like going home, so we went for a ride.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then it's true, dammit! I had a miserable time tonight 'cause of you. When the Monotones did "Book of Love  Chapter Four you break up, won't you give it just one more chance..." I'm thinking Did we break up? 'Cause if we did, I don't even know about it!. I thought we cleared all that up yesterday. Did that Maynard G. Beatnik give you what you wanted?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know I never could stand your sarcasm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're going to blow it, Peggy Sue. Nobody treats Charlie Bodell like this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And why do you always refer to yourself in the third person, like Napoleon? How come it always turns into an argument with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I've got the hair, got the eyes, got the teeth, I got the car. I'm the lead singer, I'm the man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie,. I've been trying to postpone this. But what's the point? It's over. (crying) I don't want to hurt you. This is very hard for me. I'm doing this for both of us. I really want you to be happy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will be happy if I have you. I love you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That won't make any difference. We just can't live together. And you had the nerve to drive up with that bimbo Janet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking about? Who's Janet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just can't trust you anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about everything I said to you this afternoon...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's just it. You can always get to me. There's this window in my heart and every time I leave it open, you climb in. Unless I close it now, nothing's ever going to be different!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But what has to be different?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything. I have a good head for business, I should be franchising the bakery. And I want you to give me your word that whatever happens, you'll go to college. And finish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What! What about the group and my singing career? What about me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm trying to save you years of frustration... waiting for a big break... no. Waiting for that big disappointment so you could blame it all on me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't know zip! You think I'm going to end up selling appliances like my father? Chasing women around the store. I've got to give it a shot. Why are you trying to kill the two things that mean the most to me? Until yesterday you loved me and you loved us. (opening the door) ) What the hell has changed? For two years I've done nothing but love you. I'll show you, I'm going to be just like Fabian! Charlie exits. Peggy slumps back, drained. Getting up, she crosses to the mounted swordfish. Standing on a chair she reaches into the mouth of the fish and pulls out a package of Pall Malls. She puts a cigarette in her mouth and picks up a table lighter and flicks it. As it lights, the tiny music box inside PLAYS SMOKE GETS IN YOUR EYES.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: PLAYS SMOKE GETS IN YOUR EYES

direction.raw_text: We HEAR distant CHURCH BELLS. Peggy sits down to scan the large Sunday newspaper. Seeing her mother's phone book, she finds the number she needs and picks up the phone. She dials slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Grandma. It's Peggy Sue. Much better. How are you? I'm very sorry about the other day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy jogs towards Richard. He is watering the front lawn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Richard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jogging. I was running, now I'm jogging.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what you were talking about yesterday? Everybody does that in the future?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yep. It's going to be a law. (beat) I broke up with Charlie last night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's terrific. You did it. You really changed the course of your destiny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was an unfair fight. He didn't have a chance. I'm taking a real gamble. I loved him for a long, long time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cheer up. Now you can give some other guy a shot. Make it up to him later and buy him a yacht.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For God's sake, forget the money! I'm going crazy! I'm a walking anachronism. I'm a puddle of deja I'm worried about my kids, Scott must be scared to death, I think my daughter's doing drugs again. I can't have any fun here, I don't have that innocence any more. I can't keep all this in anymore. I feel Like I'm going to explode.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, the best scientific mind in this country is working on your case. May I make a suggestion?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suggestion! Hypnotic suggestion! Why didn't I think o~ that before?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you know about hypnosis?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything. This is perfect. The subconscious mind remembers all. You can give me more information on microchips and then pinpoint what happened at the reunion. Maybe that'll give us a clue on how to get you back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I'm desperate. I'll try anything. But what if you can't snap me out of it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No offense, but you're pretty out of it now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy sits in an old recliner. Richard holds a small, batteryoperated revolving disc up in front of Peggy's closed eyes, then puts it down and picks up a notepad and pen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are completely relaxed. When I count to three, you will open your eyes. One... two... three. (Peggy's eyes flutter open) We'll start with something easy. What is your name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy Sue Kelcher. (beat) Or, Peggy Bodell. (beat) I'm not sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh boy. Peggy, what are microchips?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah..... they're very tiny... they look like a fingernail made out of an erector set...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What will they be made of?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think it's called silicon. Charlie told me that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silicon is from sand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We were lying in the sand. It was my eighteenth birthday... We were so awkward... I would have married him anyway... Peggy starts to shift in the chair. Her shorts hike up, her legs spread slightly. This is not lost on Richard. Weird, guttural sounds begin to emanate from his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the future, will you have to marry a girl before you have sex with her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. The Pill will change all that. Then he wouldn't have blamed me. We were just too young.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean you'll give a girl a pill and she'll want to have sex?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. The Pill will be for birth control. But girls do like sex. Maybe not the first time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you take of f your blouse?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, every day. (taking her blouse off getting spaced) Maybe I shouldn't have worn that dress? I told Beth it was a bad idea. That's why they made me Queen. Peggy's meandering makes Richard nervous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Richard, are you in there? Richard frantically tries to put Peggy's blouse back on. She's limp and unresponsive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Yes! I'll be right out, Dad. (urgent) Oh shit! Peggy, I'm going to snap you out of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't help it  I loved him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One... two... three. (claps twice) You are now awake. Richard kneels on top of Peggy as she wakes up, fumbling the buttons at her breasts. Peggy comes to, as Richard jumps off. She buttons her blouse, furious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Richard! You should be ashamed of yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me? You went crazy! You started taking your clothes off. I was putting them back on for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's just perfect isn't it? Did it work? Did you find out why I came back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think it has something to do with your birthday. You were rambling. I didn't understand the rest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God dammit! How'm I gonna got out of here? Peggy grabs a glass beaker and hurls it against the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey! Do you have any idea how much those beakers cost? I usually charge for hypnosis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, go feel up your hamsters! I hear rodents put out. Peggy storms out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Kelcher stands at the counter preparing a pot roast. Peggy's making a chocolate mousse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, dear, I think the pantyhose is a wonderful idea, but the next time you come up with something, please don't stay out all night. Just tell us. We'll believe you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom, how about a machine that's like your blender, only it slices vegetables, kneads dough, chops meat and even make fresh pasta?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's pasta?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy and Mrs. Kelcher are setting the table, taking the good china out of the cabinet. A dozen red roses grace the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These roses are beautiful. And so romantic'. Who is this Michael? Is he a friend of Charlie's? She moves the Jell-O mold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, just a friend of mine. I don't think he Likes JellO.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does Charlie think about that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know Mom, it's okay to have male friends. Besides, it's over with me and Charlie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? When did it happen? Your dad and I always expected you two to get married.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I know Peggy Sue gets married. Case closed. Period. Mom, if you could live your life over again, would you do the same thing? Get married and settle down after high school?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course I loved your Lather. I remember once being offered a scholarship to art school. But I turned it down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the college girls I knew were so well, dressed. I was worried that I wouldn't fit in. I didn't have the right clothes. I was so silly. But, I don't have many regrets, and besides, r don't have time to worry about the past. But Charlie. I hope you know what you're doing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DINING ROOM  TWO HOURS LATER Michael, DORIS and ED FITZSIMMONS sit at the table with the Kelchers. They have just finished dessert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Moose?  I never thought I'd have moose for desert. The adults laugh. Michael looks bored.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy Sue cooked the whole dinner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Mom helped.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, you should open a restaurant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's incredibly difficult to make money in the restaurant business. You have to get up at five in the morning to go to the market, you have problems with spoilage, employee pilferage, and just try and collect from the credit card companies. They take months to pay. The whole table is astonished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How does a young gal like you know so much about business?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I just picked it up from my dad. He's a wonderful businessman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really? Peggy gives her father a go get him look. Michael's writing in a pocket notebook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, Ed, why don't you and I adjourn to the den for a while?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy~ and Michael stand by Michael's motorcycle, passing a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was quite an evening. Bourgeois, phony, decadent, stupid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I shouldn't have put you through that. It must have been agony. Let's do something. Michael makes a move towards Peggy, with lust in his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Something else. I'm too full. Besides, it's a school night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael and Peggy pull up on the motorcycle in front of Lena's Lounge, a seedy bar in the town's black ghetto. Half a dozen blacks are banging around outside. They eye Peggy and Michael suspiciously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The room has a bar at one side, booths and tables in the rest of the room. A stage is at the far end. On stage, an all black group, The FourMations, is performing the song GOOD TIMIN' The people in the club are dancing the Twist. Peggy and Michael sit in the last booth. Several people wave hello to Michael.. Although Peggy and Michael can see the stage, their booth is not visible from the stage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five more weeks of school. And ten minutes past graduation I'm gone. (he raises his glass) To freedom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: crowd  clinking glasses) For everyone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now listen, this is the plan. As soon as school is finished we go to Utah and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Utah? I thought you'd be going to New York or Paris. What's in Utah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rita. I met her last summer. She's cool. You'll really dig her. She's got this great little cabin in the hills, just outside of Provo where she raises chickens. I'll write and the two of you can take care of the chickens to support us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't do that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not? Polygamy's legal in Utah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hate chickens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THE STAGE On stage, the FourNations have concluded their song. We HEAR APPLAUSE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Now we're happy to introduce, a friend of ours. He's one damn fine singer, Mr. Charlie Dell! We HEAR the GROVE BEGIN the SONG SEA OF LOVE. MICHAEL But what about the other night? We were like two stars in the same constellation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael, you and I are light years apart. You should go, but not with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But we had heat baby. Passion! Fire! We owe it to ourselves to fuse together. (beat) At least one more time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's a terrific line. You're going to be a wonderful writer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think so?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. We had a glorious night together. One day you'll remember and write about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can dig that. Bittersweet perfection. Dogs of lust on leashes of memory... yeah. Suddenly distracted by the familiar voice, Peggy looks up to the stage and sees that the lead singer, Charlie Bell, is in fact, Charlie Bodell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (0.S.) It's Charlie!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a treat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Michael observes Peggy's intimate reaction to Charlie's singing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now I get it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ssh. He's great.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy Sue's still stuck on treble without a cause. Charlie finishes the song as the audience goes wild. He beams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought I knew everything about him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can we split now? Peggy and Michael unobtrusively slip out of the club. Charlie leaves the stage. He's met by a greasy looking MAN. They sit down at a booth to talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KELCHER HOUSE  NIGHT Michael and Peggy pull up. Peggy gets off the bike and gives Michael a goodnight kiss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can dig you being uptight about Rita and Utah. That's cool. But I've got to warn you about something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My father. He's not just the ultimate square. He's a total crook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Kelcher finishes the dishes, with rubber gloves on. Mr. Kelcher sits, cleaning his pipe. Peggy enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did it go with the pantyhose?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the darndest thing. Ed knew what they were immediately. As a matter of fact, he said he's got a product like that in development right now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh no!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't call, them pantyhose, though. What was it, Evelyn?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sheerotards. Catchy name, isn't it? Like leotards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a liar! He has no such thing! It's my own fault. I should have had it patented first. He's a crook, damnit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy Sue, watch your mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Fitzsimmons is a very prominent man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, you're both so naive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look young lady, I grew up through the depression. I fought in the second World War. Six days a week I get up and deal with the public, the bank and the bill collectors. And on the seventh day, when God rests, I don't have to listen to my daughter calling me a fool!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have a point, dear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (POSS. OMIT THIS SCENE) Peggy lies in bed in the darkness, her eyes wide open. The bedside clock reads: 2:47. Peggy gets out of bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy into Nancy's room. Peggy looks down at Nancy sleeping. Gently pulling back the blankets, Peggy gets into bed with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CHARLIE'S STREET  MORNING Peggy walks down a residential street, much like her parents'. She stops when she sees Charlie's car parked in a driveway, and leans against a tree next to his car. Moments later, Charlie exits his house, a dog trailing behind him. The dog runs up to Peggy. Charlie is wary and distant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What're you doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted to talk to you, and I have one last thing to take care of at school. Then I'm going to... (pats dog) Good dog, Rusty. Good dog.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rusty's dead. That's Ajax Charlie throws a stick. Ajax chases it, never comes back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. I guess I always liked Rusty better. (beat) Could you give me a ride to school?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, the Blue Thunder's out of commission for a while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, how about a walk, Charlie Bell..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How'd you know about that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was at Lena's last night. You were terrific.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not terrific enough. What were you doing in that part of town? Who were you with?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What were You doing there? You never told me you were singing with an R and B group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey. I guess there's a lot of things we don't know about each other. Charlie and Peggy walking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd forgotten how much music meant to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's real big of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop being defensive. I want to help you. I wrote a song for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're kidding. You wrote a song? Is it about a guilty girl and a trusting guy... she wants to hurt him, and he wonders why? Peggy takes a piece of paper from her purse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not exactly, but with your great voice, it'll be a huge hit. Honest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fat chance. You know, Lee Wilkins came to hear me last night. He told me to forget it. You told me to forget it. My parents tell me to forget it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just take a look at it. (hands him the lyric)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you took the trouble to write it, then sure, I'll take a look at it. But I'm beginning to think that maybe there's more to life than music. I wonder if people would still like me if I stopped being Mr. Excitement?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy and Charlie stand by their open locker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does this mean you like me again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It means I care about you and what happens to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all I wanted to hear. 'Cause I'm never going to give up on us. It's easy to fall apart in a crisis. It's easy to be selfish and say goodbye and good luck. But this is more than love. This is a mental decision. Just wait till tomorrow, when you see your birthday present. Then you'll understand. Charlie walks away as Peggy reaches into the locker for her books.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy, I have to talk to you. Peggy turns to Carol. They walk down the hallway together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's that jerk Walter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After Charlie told Walter that he broke up with you because he wanted to play the field, Walter decided he should do the same thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Welcome to the singles' scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a I going to do for the rest of my life? I don't have a boyfriend anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, Carol, maybe Walter's done you a big favor. You always said you wanted to get out of town. Go for it. And be happy, goddamnit, I'm rooting for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walter walks up to Charlie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey Charlie, what do you think of this? Walter does a totally demented dance step, finishing by strumming his leg like a guitar. He stands there grinning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walter, maybe you should be a dentist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy sits at her desk, organizing her books. We hear the end of the ANNOUNCEMENTS over the P.A. SYSTEM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And finally, our heartiest congratulations to our girls diving team for placing second in the county finals last Friday. And a special accolade to Rosalie Testa who placed first in every one of her events. We're proud of you, Rosalie. Everybody turns toward Rosalie and applauds. Peggy turns to Rosalie, trembling. The BELL RINGS as the class starts to leave, still crowded around Rosalie. Peggy stares after her, frozen in her seat Dolores approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter, princess? Lost your prince? Peggy looks up at Dolores and starts to seethe. She stands up slowly and faces Dolores.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know Dolores, there's a lot of things I could say to you, but you're not worth the effort. Peggy reaches down to        up her books. On the top of the pile is an open fountain pen, which she picks up, pul1ing the release lever, squirting ink all over Dolores's dress. Dolores drops her books, looks down at her dress, horrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry. These fountain pens are so tricky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh! You did that on purpose! I hate you. Go gargle with razor blades!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I beg your pardon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take a long walk on a short pier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have a nice day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy sits disconsolate on a bench, watching the other girls changing into their swim suits. Rosalie is in the shower room, wetting down her suit. She accepts congratulations from a number of the girls. The BELL RINGS as the girls begin to exit to the pool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rosalie! Wait! Rosalie turns at the door, smiling. They are alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think you should give up diving. It's dangerous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be silly, I'm the best in the county.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you are, but you have to stop. I couldn't tell you before, I didn't know if I should. But you have to stop before you hurt yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I spend three hours a day practicing. I have trainers, I know what I'm doing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But accidents can happen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not to me they don't. I'm going to win the State, then the. Nationals, and then I'm going to the Olympics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rosalie, please, listen to me! You have to stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're sick. You should go to the nurse. I'm going to tell Miss Dennis. Rosalie exits into the pool area. Peggy feels helpless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy walks down the hall, a set of double doors, leading to the pool, just ahead of her through them she sees Rosalie diving through the air with the careless innocence of youth. Burdened with the inevitability of it all, she rushes through the hall, and is stopped by Richard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all, gone wrong, nothing's working out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not true.  I think I'm making real progress on the microchip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were meant to. You're one of those fortunate people that good things happen to. I have to get out of here. She starts to walk away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy, I believe you. I believe everything you told me. It's wonderful. You're the exception that proves the rule. She kisses him on the forehead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you too, Richard. Thanks for trying. She continues down the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy heads out the door, sees Charlie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Peggy. Wait a minute. Peggy stops on the landing. Charlie joins her, so eager. He doesn't notice how distraught she is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I cut shop and did some work on your song. You know, it's not half bad for your first try. Of course, I changed all the "yeahs" to "oohs". Listen to this. Charlie begins to sing an R&B version of SHE LOVES YOU.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forget it, it'll never work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Listen, I cancelled the tickets for Fabian. I thought it would be better for your birthday to eat at a nice restaurant, Chez Tres. Walter, Arthur, Maddy and Carol watch as Peggy runs away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the bus, Peggy looking out the window, the rural scenery: pastures, barns, etc., the other passengers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy's grandparents, ELIZABETH and BARNEY ALVORG , wait in the front of the station.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy sees her grandparents waiting for her.  She grips the window rail tightly, trying to hold herself together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody gettin' off at Dumont. Here we are. Peggy stands and reaches above to take down her suitcase. Nervous, she drops it. A MAN, getting off the bus, helps her, picking it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No trouble at all. The man gets off the bus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy stands at the door of the bus, hesitant. Elizabeth and Barney approach the bus, waving and smiling up at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Lilla!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy Sue! Peggy slowly walks down the steps, moved to tears. She approaches her grandparents and drops her suitcases. She hugs them tightly. The bus door closes and the bus pulls away behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barney is behind the wheel of a 1951 Plymouth. Elizabeth is in front, Peggy curled up in the back, regressing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quite a bit more rain than usual this year. I hope it doesn't spoil the rhubarb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've already got some in. I was thinking of making a pie for dinner tonight. (turning around to Peggy) How would you like that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. (beat) ) Grandma, would you teach me how to make strudel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's a day's work. But if that's what you want, maybe we can do it tomorrow for your birthday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy and Elizabeth finish up the dishes, chatting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A fire blazes in the fireplace. A grandfather clock stands prominently in the room. The clock from Peggy's house. Peggy sits with Elizabeth, learning how to knit. Barney laughs at "The Burns and Allen Show" on TV. Suddenly, Peggy places her hand over her heart and shivers with fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter, Lilla? Somebody jump on your grave? Peggy shivers again and shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barney reading. Elizabeth enters, carrying a tray with cups of cocoa. They each take a cup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, Peggy Sue, your mother said you had a dream that I died.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish she hadn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not afraid. I know exactly when I'm going to die. Peggy is perplexed by her grandmother's apparent lack of fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's it going to be, Elizabeth? Seventyfive? Eighty?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not telling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been trying to drag it out of her for years. (beat) You know, dreams are fascinating business. 'Specially where you see the future.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you believe in all of that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I like to speculate. This book I'm reading right now, a woman in Colorado says she lived in Ireland a hundred and fifty years ago. Her name was Bridey Murphy- and she gives names and dates and where she lived. She was hypnotized. Big bestseller.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I remember that book! (beat) Grandpa, Grandma, I want to tell you something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FARMHOUSE KITCHEN  DAY Peggy and Elizabeth are making strudel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you believe it, darling, then I believe. Being young can be just as confusing as being old. The things that happened to me fifty years ago are more on my mind than what happened yesterday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I'm remembering the future.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right now you're just browsing through time. Choose the things you'll be proud of. The things that Last.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My children make me happy. I miss them so much. (beat) Beth. Scott and Beth. (beat) I'm going to name my daughter after you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FARMHOUSE DRIVEWAY  DUSK Peggy and Barney are washing the car at a standpipe, two hundred feet from the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's gonna rain again. Every time I wash the car, it rains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That never changes. (beat) You know, when you and Grandma are gone, the family's gone. I never see the cousins anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's your grandma's strudel that's kept this family together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grandpa, if you had a chance to do it all again, what would you do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd take better care of my teeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elizabeth is tying Barney's bow tie. Peggy is sitting with a jacket on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's Peggy Sue going to do at your lodge meeting?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's her 18th birthday, I want to show her off. Barney turns and winks at Peggy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was my idea, Grandma. I always wondered what went on at those lodge meetings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He won't tell me, but I've got my suspicions. And I don't want any of that. Don't keep her out late.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodbye, Grandma.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have a good time. Barney and Peggy open the door and exit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy and Barney approach the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does Grandma think you do at your meetings?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stag movies. Smokers. Peggy chuckles as they get into the car. The car proceeds along the driveway and turns onto the highway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barney is at the wheel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I may be an old fool, but I think we can help you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope so. At least I got to see you and Grandma. (beat) Has it ever worked before?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The last one was six hundred years ago. It's about time for another one.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: THE ORDER OF THE GOLDEN DAWN
result.heading: THE ORDER OF THE GOLDEN DAWN

direction.raw_text: A onestory, pitchroof building. The sign over the entrance reads.: THE ORDER OF THE GOLDEN DAWN. Underneath the sign is a logo of a spreading sunrise. Peggy and Barney pull up to the front, exit the car and enter the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thirty old men are congregating around the cloak room. Most are already dressed in long, purple robes with the sunrise logo over their hearts. They either wear or carry tricorner hats. Peggy and Barney enter. Several men approach them. Peggy nervously clings to Barney' s arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Welcome, Peggy Sue. It's nice to have you with us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, you're a lucky girl. You could lay a bear trap in the aisle of the cathedral and never catch a better man than your grandfather.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah... thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me take your jacket, Lilla. I've got, to get my robe. Peggy hands him her jacket as he heads over to the cloak, room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, this is very exciting for all of us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've been waiting a long time for someone like you. Barney rejoins them, wearing his hat and robe. The group begins to enter the main room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have to wear that hat?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It wouldn't be a lodge without hats. Barney takes her hand and squeezes it. They walk slowly through the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you worry. I'll be watching after you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A large meeting hall. The room is draped, and brightly lit with fluorescent lights. At one end sits a large, gold painted wood throne. On either side are large candle holders, with lit candles. A small table serves as an altar in front of the platform. On a footstool is a potted plane with an artificial bird perched on its top. The throne and altar look like a set left over from a summer stock "Macbeth". Peggy and Barney enter. Several men lead Peggy away from Barney to the throne. One man places a go1den cape around her shoulders. They lead her up the platform to the throne.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, George. Get the lights. The LIGHTS are DIMMED. The room is lit by the candles. The men form a semicircle around Peggy. Old men at the end of their lives, they are serious and passionate about the possibilities of life beyond this world. One by one, four men from either end of the line approach the altar with offerings: a cup of wine; an egg; a gold coin; and a rose. The men rejoin the line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a tall, whitehaired man, takes two steps forward. The other men begin to sing a Gregorian chant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you ready, dear?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. Leo steps back, closes his eyes and spreads his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fasten your seat belts. Here we go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lord of the Universe, Vast and Mighty One. Ruler of Light, King of~ the sun. Creator of earth, air, fire and water. (kneeling down) We adore thee and invoke thee! Grant thine aid. Look with favor upon us as we witness the regeneration of man. We behold the innocent endeavors of singleminded men and women. For we are the company of unbodied souls and immortal angels. We ask thy intervention, that this girl may return to thee on the wings of your Love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is never going to work. The old men form a circle in front of Peggy. They begin to circumambulate east to west, intoning together, their heads bowed. As Barney passes in front of Peggy, he winks at her. She smiles back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fount of life, Chariot of the Spirit, Womb of the Mother, reclaim thy child of light. We HEAR a clap of distant THUNDER. Peggy trembles. The artificial bird falls off the plant. Peggy is struck with amazement. She begins to glow, poised to take off. The men continue to chant while:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The name of your love is sacrifice. We offer up this girl, that her soul may find its home. Suddenly a door is opened, a gust of wind pours in and extinguishes the candles, plunging the hall into darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing to worry about. Somebody get the lights. The LIGHTS are TURNED ON. All the men look to the throne. Peggy is gone. They are speechless for a couple of beats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, the girl's gone. Let's play some poker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He smiles, happy that she made it. George crosses to the wall, reaches behind the drapes and presses a button. The wall slides open to reveal a fullyequipped card room. The men shuffle in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie carries Peggy off towards his car, one hand covering her mouth. Peggy struggles. When they reach the car, he puts her down. She's still wrapped in her golden robe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell did you do that for? What are you doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was trying to save you. They were going to vaporize you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be ridiculous! They're just a bunch of harmless old men. My grandfather was in there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're going to listen to me. Charlie tries to Lead Peggy into the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not getting in that blue monstrosity. Charlie pushes her inside, Peggy climbs back out. Charlie takes her hand and drags her up a hill behind the lodge hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me got! Where are you taking me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right here. Now sit down. Charlie sits her down on the ground. She's impatient and hopping mad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look. I wanna tell you. I forgive you for everything. I know what you've been going through. You're just scared. I was scared, too, but I'm not anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How could you possibly know what I've been going through? Thunder and lightning. It starts to rain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I love you, damnit! I had a long talk with your father yesterday and we decided that the best thing for us to do is get married and settle down. Right away. Peggy jumps up, exploding to Charlie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean you and my father decided? Who the hell are you to plan my life? Let's get married and live happily ever after. Bullshit. I got knocked up. I had to marry you. I never had a choice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You betrayed me, Charlie. You were never there for me or the children. And now you come and tell me, "Peggy, you're scared." Of course I'm scared. If you knew what I knew you'd be scared shitless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're crazy! You're really out of your mind!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I might be crazy, but I'm not crazy enough to marry you twice. There's a lot of things I can't change. I can't even think about them. I tried. But I couldn't even help Rosalie. (tears start) I don't want to be bitter. I'm a naturally optimistic person. But you took advantage of that. Charlie bends down to comfort her, in tears. He hugs Peggy and strokes her hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Peggy. My poor Peggy. It's all my fault. I'm so sorry. I won't bother you anymore. I promise. Please stop crying. Please. Peggy starts to compose herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you take me back to my grandparents?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. Charlie helps her up. Be reaches into his pocket and takes out a small box, handing it to Peggy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's almost your birthday. I wasn't sure when you were coming back, so I brought your present up here. With a slow, growing remembrance, Peggy opens the box. Inside is the gold locket Peggy was wearing at the reunion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Charlie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It opens, too. Look inside. Peggy opens the locket. She shivers with recognition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two photos, one of Peggy, one of Charlie, as children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scott and Beth. Where did you get these?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's Scott and Beth? Your mother gave me our picture. That's you and me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So are Scott and Beth. Peggy leans into Charlie, throwing her arms around him, holding on for dear life. She looks up at him, their foreheads touching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. Charlie kisses her, passionately. The locket drops to the ground. HOLD on the locket, and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie and Peggy are lying on the ground, gazing up. A flash of lightning streaks across the sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think we should get out of here. It's going to rain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think anybody in the Fifties ever made love on a bed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell is that? Flying high above them is an enormous, glowing, liquid neon kite. The center of the kite inscribed in lights, flashing like a marquee: HAPPY BIRTHDAY PEGGY SUE. The kite begins to descend towards them. Peggy jumps to her feet and races towards it. She grabs the tail and starts to sail away with the kite. Charlie chases after her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy! Where're you going? Come back!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got to go now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I love you. I'll love you forever.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll love you, too, Charlie. I'll love you for twenty years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come back to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm trying. As Charlie watches helplessly, a huge bolt of lightning strikes his car. Peggy smiles. The men from the lodge run outside. They look up and above the blazing car and see Peggy floating away. Peggy sees her grandfather in the crowd and blows him a kiss. Charlie begins to run, following the kite cord to its source. He finds Richard, struggling to restrain the runaway kite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Richard, do something!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't! It's out of control! Suddenly the cord breaks. Peggy floats away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peggy! Charlie, Richard and the old men behold Peggy, bobbing and dipping playfully in the sky. We begin to HEAR Charlie's
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: singing "Peggy Sue" O.S. Peggy looks down with wonder at the earth, and then like a comet, soars into the blackness. In an instant she becomes a star.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Moving from two to C.U. Peggy, fragments of the reunion, the cake coming towards her, fragments of words in echo effect: 'Your heart stopped for a while..." Father's voice: 'You're a very lucky young lady...' Doctor: 'A (explain) of the head...' Mom's voice: 'But you're going to be all right now, the paramedics got there...' Mom, 'We were so worried..." Echoing of, until once voice is left. Charlie. Sitting opposite her bed, as he has been every minute of her illness. He looks wan and old, worried sick, but trying to sing 'Peggy Sue' for her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (singing softly). Peggy Sue, I love you, and I need you Peggy Sue...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie? Was I dead?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you were...for a while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look awful, like you haven't slept in days. And so old.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But happy. Very happy, Peggy Sue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlie, I thought I knew everything about you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted to apologize. I can't live without you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about Janet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's over. I got tired of translating everything. She thought the Big Hopper was a hamburger. Charlie laughs uncomfortably and Peggy Sue looks around her hospital room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are all the flowers from? Charlie pushes himself out of his chair and moves toward the dresser.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone.  Maddie and Arthur, Carol and Walter. Richard Norvick.  And here's a book, by that guy from high school, Michael Fitzsimmons. He dedicated it to you. Charlie returns to Peggy's bedside and opens the front cover of the book.
direction.name: direction
